instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .

threads.title: 00165 Weird CPU problem
threads.message:
Have a 00165 with some issue. The CPU is getting warm just like the other one I did but there is no short to ground betwixt VCORE and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>-8.58V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>-3.43V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.42
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.29
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.42
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.39
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.58

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0

<SIGNAL>PPVCOMP_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>- 0
VCORE- 9.5 Ohm resistance to ground

CPU is warm? Wierd

S4s arent running... of course... Ideas??

threads.title: 00165 Weird CPU problem
threads.message:
Really strange thay CPU gets warm, when only <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present.
Could be PCH issue, as you miss <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> I suppose.
I can only think to VCCRTC issue of PCH.

Remove heatsink and tocuh PCH die (small one).
If that heats, most likely VCCRTC problem.
Check resistance to ground on it.

threads.title: 00165 Weird CPU problem
threads.message: Indeed it is the PCH portion that is getting warm. Is there a separate VCCRTC? PPVRTC is 16K Ohms to Ground... VCCRTC is within and I cant test it... However ppvrtc connects directly to it.

threads.title: 00165 Weird CPU problem
threads.message:
Actually VCCRTC is the PCH labelling,  You are in the RTC portion of the PCH and the name of the power rail going into VCCRTC is <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>. Yep I had the same issue a few weeks ago on exactly the same board.

However, your resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> doesn't look like a short...
On my good bord I have 12kohms on the shorted one it's like 3ohms...

Let us know about :
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V, Is it a short?
Do you have <SIGNAL>P3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>?  You need both <SIGNAL>P3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>.
Are you missing (most likely) <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: 00165 Weird CPU problem
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> also goes to PCH.
Don't waste time, if PCH heats without any other voltage than 3V42 and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, board is trash.
Not always short, or low value in a power rail point to a bad chip.
Even for high value there, one bad chip can go into some avalanche process when is powered up...
